item.title: Jwt Token
item.description: What is JWT Token ? A JSON Web Token (JWT) consists of three parts separated by periods (.): the header, the payload, and the signature. Each part is Base64-encoded. Example JWT: Header: { "alg": "HS256", "typ": "JWT" } Encoded in Base64, the header becomes: eyJhbGciOiAiSFMyNTYiLCAidHlwIjogIkpXVCJ9 Payload: { "sub": "1234567890", "name": "John Doe", "iat": 1516239022 } Encoded in Base64, the payload becomes: eyJzdWIiOiAiMTIzNDU2Nzg5MCIsICJuYW1lIjogIkpvaG4gRG9lIiwgICJpYXQiOiAxNTE2MjM5MDIyfQ Signature: The signature is generated using the algorithm specified in the header (here, “HS256”).

item.title: Keyboard with RubberDucky
item.description: Integration of a Rubber Ducky into a USB Keyboard Objective: We are increasingly faced with the presence of dangerous USB keys. However, keyboards can also be a means of injecting malicious code into your computer. We will see how to create a keyboard with a Rubber Ducky. Nevertheless, for security reasons, no code will be disclosed. Hardware Firstly, a soldering set will be necessary, and you need some basic skills to complete this project.

item.title: Proxmark 3
item.description: 1 - Implementation of the Tool In the first step, I will equip myself with my tool: The Proxmark 3 Easy, you can find this little gadget on AliExpress for around 50â‚¬. It has two antennas, one for low frequency and one for high frequency. To use it, you will need a tool called Iceman. YouTube tutorial for updating the firmware and installing Iceman: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n1Xt-1ZmjM0&feature=emb_imp_woyt 2 - Identifying the Badge To identify the badge, we will use the ‘auto’ command, which allows scanning across different frequencies (high and low frequencies).
